summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the US v. Maxwell case, primarily discussing discovery issues. Defense attorney Laura Menninger raises numerous problems with accessing and reviewing evidence, including corrupt files, unviewable photos, discrepancies in counts of 'highly confidential' materials, and requests for access to evidence containing nude images of adults. The correspondence highlights significant logistical and procedural challenges in the pre-trial discovery process.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is the primary correspondent in the email chain, raising multiple discovery deficiencies and requesting access to evidence, including 'highly confidential' materials.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney (USANYS) copied on the email chain, involved in the discovery conferral process for the prosecution.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the email chain regarding discovery issues.

connections.description: Prosecutor and defense attorney corresponding about discovery issues in the US v. Maxwell case, demonstrating an adversarial but professional working relationship.
Both are defense attorneys representing Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the same discovery-related emails.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date
events.description: The trial for US v. Maxwell is scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021, as mentioned in the correspondence.

events.title: Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Defense counsel traveled to New York to review evidence in the government's possession, including 'highly confidential' material, but encountered technical problems with hard drives and readers.

locations: Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. office)
New York, NY (location of evidence review at 500 Pearl)
Colorado (FBI office proposed for evidence review)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Ghislaine Maxwell is held)
keyFacts: The defense reports significant discovery problems: thousands of photos are unreadable, corrupt files, missing metadata, and discrepancies in the count of 'highly confidential' images (initially said to be ~2,100, but an FBI report indicates ~34,000).

The prosecution defines 'Highly Confidential' material broadly as containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or other depictions of individuals' and insists defense can only view it under law enforcement supervision, not possess copies.

The defense argues the 'Highly Confidential' designation is overly broad, noting some images only show 'a woman's back or shoulder,' and requests access to all such material except potential child pornography.
The correspondence references a '3D scan of Epstein's private island' among the produced materials, indicating the scope of evidence seized.
The email chain reveals ongoing, unresolved technical and procedural disputes about evidence access that the defense suggests may require court intervention.
